over.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: above or higher than something, without touching it
over.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: A lamp hung over the table.
She leaned over the desk to answer the phone.
The sign over the door said ‘Mind your head’.
We watched a helicopter flying low over the harbour.
over.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Over the body lay a thin white sheet.
She wore a large jacket over her sweater.
Mind you don’t spill coffee over my best tablecloth.
over.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: from one side of something to the other side of it
over.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Somehow the sheep had jumped over the fence.
The road over the mountains is steep and dangerous.
a bridge over the River Thames
Their house has a magnificent view over the bay.
over.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: on the opposite side of something from where you already are
over.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: There’s a bus stop just over the road.
They live over the river in Richmond.
over.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: down from the edge of something
over.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The car plunged over a cliff.
over.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: in or to many parts of a particular place, organization, or thing
over.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: He used to wander over the moors, losing all track of time.
They said they had cleaned up but there were bottles all over the place.
Scientists from all over the world gather here.
over.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: if you are over an illness or a bad experience or situation, you are no longer affected by it
over.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: I think we’re over the worst of the crisis now.
He had a fever last night, but he seems to be over it now.
Sybil has never got over the shock of her mother’s death.
I’m over him now  (=I am no longer in love with him).
over.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: more than a particular number, amount, or level
over.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: The Japanese were producing over 100 million tons of steel.
toys suitable for children over the age of three
drivers who go over the speed limit
a social club for the over-60s
over.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Will you be home over the summer vacation?
Over a period of ten years he stole a million pounds from the company.
Can we talk about this over dinner?
over.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: about a particular subject, person, or thing
over.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: He’s having problems over his income tax.
There is concern over the bad image of the legal profession.
over.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: in control of or influencing someone or something
over.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Genghis ruled over an empire that stretched from Persia across to China.
She had great personal influence and power over her followers.
over.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: used to say that someone or something is more successful or better than someone or something else
over.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: Can Labour maintain its lead over the Conservatives?
It has one great advantage over its rivals.
over.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: using something such as a telephone or radio
over.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: I don’t want to talk about this over the telephone.
I heard the news over the radio.
over.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: making a sound louder than another sound
over.translation[0].definitions[13].exam: ‘What?’ he yelled over the noise of the engine and the wind.
over.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: if you choose one thing over another, you choose that thing rather than the other
over.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: What is your main reason for choosing one restaurant over another?
over.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: from an upright position into a position of lying on a surface
over.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: He was so drunk he fell over in the road.
Mind you don’t knock the candle over.
Engineers are working to prevent the tower from toppling over.
over.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: so that someone or something is no longer straight or flat, but is bent or folded in the middle
over.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: As Sheila bent over, a sudden pain shot up her back.
He folded the paper over and put it in his pocket.
over.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: from one side of an object, space, or area to the other side
over.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: There are only three canoes so some people will have to swim over.
The wall was crumbling where children had climbed over.
I went over  (=crossed the room, street etc) to say hello, but Vincent didn’t recognize me.
We flew over to the US to visit my Aunt Polly.
One of my cousins is coming over from France with his wife and daughter.
Come over here and see what I’ve found.
over.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: in a place that is on the other side of a space or area
over.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Bill lives over on the other side of town.
She was standing over by the window.
Do you see that building over there?
over.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: in or to a particular house, city etc
over.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: You really should come over and see our new house.
I spent the whole day over at Gabby’s place.
We could drive over to Oxford this afternoon.
over.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: if an event or period of time is over, it has finished
over.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: I’m so glad the mid-term exams are over and done with.
You’d better give them the bad news. Do it now – get it over with.
over.translation[1].definitions[6].examp: The bus pulled over to the side of the road.
Would you move over, so I can sit next to you.
over.translation[1].definitions[7].defin: from one person or group to another
over.translation[1].definitions[7].examp: The attacker was ordered to hand over his weapon.
Most of the money has been signed over to his children.
over.translation[1].definitions[8].defin: from one position or system to another
over.translation[1].definitions[8].examp: The guards change over at midnight.
We switched over from electricity to gas because it was cheaper.
over.translation[1].definitions[9].defin: so that the bottom or the other side of something can now be seen
over.translation[1].definitions[9].examp: Turn the box over and open it at that end.
Josh rolled over and went back to sleep.
over.translation[1].definitions[10].defi: more than or higher than a particular number, amount, or level
over.translation[1].definitions[10].exam: Almost 40% of women are size 14 or over.
People earning £33,000 and over will pay the higher rate of tax.
over.translation[1].definitions[11].defi: used before an adjective or adverb to mean ‘very’ or ‘too’
over.translation[1].definitions[11].exam: She didn’t seem over pleased when I asked her to wait.
Perhaps we were all over enthusiastic about the project.
over.translation[1].definitions[12].defi: an amount of something that is over is what remains after some of it has been used
over.translation[1].definitions[12].exam: There should be some money over when I’ve paid all the bills.
There was a little food left over from the party.
over.translation[1].definitions[13].defi: used to show that something is completely covered with a substance or material
over.translation[1].definitions[13].exam: Most of the windows have been boarded over.
Parts of the river were iced over.
The door had been painted over with a bright red varnish.
over.translation[1].definitions[14].exam: We stood on the roof watching the planes fly over.
over.translation[1].definitions[15].defi: in a detailed and careful way
over.translation[1].definitions[15].exam: After talking it over with my wife, I’ve decided to retire.
I’ll need time to read the contract over before I sign.
Think it over carefully before you make a decision.
over.translation[1].definitions[16].defi: if you start or do something over, you do it again
over.translation[1].definitions[16].exam: I got mixed up and had to start over.
over.translation[1].definitions[17].defi: used when communicating by radio to show that you have finished speaking
over.translation[1].definitions[17].exam: Are you hearing me loud and clear? Over.
over.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the period of time in the game of cricket during which six or eight balls are thrown by the same bowler in one direction
over.translation[3].definitions[1].examp: the overland route  (=not by sea or air)
over.translation[3].definitions[3].examp: We were working overtime (=working beyond the usual time).
